problem: Let positive integers \( K \) and \( d \) be given. Prove that there exists a positive integer \( n \) and a sequence of \( K \) positive integers \( b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{K} \) such that the number \( n \) is a \( d \)-digit palindrome in all number bases \( b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{K} \).

grading_scheme.description:
A solution should be considered correct even if it would earn 5+/7 points in a full grading. Examples of small penalties worth 1 point are if the solution:

  • Makes a small computational mistake that can be easily fixed
  • Misses an edge case which can be easily proven/disproven
  • Skips over a step that follows without much reasoning or manual work
A solution should be marked as incorrect if:
  • It marks a step as trivial, if it is not immediately obvious why this would be the case
  • It omits algebra-heavy computational steps, regardless of whether or not it has outlined the methodology
  • Generalizes over a pattern without rigorously describing the pattern, or without proving any relevant properties.
  • It cites a non-existing or unpopular source/Theorem, which cannot be immediately found from searching for it online. Thus, any theorems that can be immediately found and have a Wikipedia article are allowed.
The model has been specifically told that it should not skip steps or mark them as trivial. Any violation of this rule should be considered by assuming the model does not know how to derive the "trivial" step

attempts.solution:
To prove that for any given positive integers \(K\) and \(d\), there exists a positive integer \(n\) and a sequence of \(K\) positive integers \(b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_K\) such that \(n\) is a \(d\)-digit palindrome in all bases \(b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_K\), the following approach is used.

First, consider the case where \(d = 1\). A 1-digit palindrome in any base \(b \geq 2\) is any number from 1 to \(b-1\), as it consists of a single digit and thus reads the same forwards and backwards. Choose \(n = 1\) and set all bases \(b_i = 2\) for \(i = 1\) to \(K\). In base 2, \(n = 1\) is represented as \(1_2\), which is a 1-digit number and hence a palindrome. Since the number of digits is 1 and the digit is symmetric, \(n = 1\) is a 1-digit palindrome in each base \(b_i = 2\). The sequence of bases is \((2, 2, \ldots, 2)\) with \(K\) elements, all positive integers greater than or equal to 2.

Now consider the case where \(d \geq 2\). Choose a base \(b > 1\), for example, \(b = 10\). Define \(n = b^{d-1} + 1\). In base \(b\), the number \(n = b^{d-1} + 1\) has the digit representation with the most significant digit 1, followed by \(d-2\) zeros (if \(d > 2\)), and the least significant digit 1. For example:
- If \(d = 2\), \(n = b + 1\), and in base \(b\), it is represented as \((1, 1)_b\), which is a palindrome.
- If \(d = 3\), \(n = b^2 + 1\), and in base \(b\), it is represented as \((1, 0, 1)_b\), which is a palindrome.

To verify that \(n\) has exactly \(d\) digits in base \(b\):
- The smallest \(d\)-digit number in base \(b\) is \(b^{d-1}\), and \(n = b^{d-1} + 1 > b^{d-1}\).
- The largest \(d\)-digit number in base \(b\) is \(b^d - 1\), and \(n = b^{d-1} + 1 \leq b^d - 1\) for \(b \geq 2\) and \(d \geq 2\), since \(b^{d-1} + 1 < b^d\) for \(b > 1\).

Thus, \(n = b^{d-1} + 1\) has exactly \(d\) digits in base \(b\) and is a palindrome. Set all bases \(b_i = b = 10\) for \(i = 1\) to \(K\). Then, in each base \(b_i = 10\), \(n = 10^{d-1} + 1\) is a \(d\)-digit palindrome. The sequence of bases is \((10, 10, \ldots, 10)\) with \(K\) elements, all positive integers.

This construction works for any \(K\) and \(d \geq 2\). Combining both cases, for any positive integers \(K\) and \(d\), the required \(n\) and sequence \(b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_K\) exist.

\boxed{\text{For given positive integers } K \text{ and } d, \text{ let } b \text{ be a positive integer greater than 1 (for example, } b=10\text{). Set all } b_i = b \text{ for } i=1 \text{ to } K. \text{ Let } n = b^{d-1} + 1 \text{ if } d \geq 2, \text{ and for } d=1, \text{ set } n=1 \text{ and } b_i=2 \text{ for all } i. \text{ Then } n \text{ is a } d\text{-digit palindrome in each base } b_i.} }

result.summary: The proof splits into two cases. For d=1 it takes n=1 and all bases b_i=2 so that 1 is a 1-digit palindrome in each base. For d≥2 it fixes an arbitrary base b (e.g. b=10), sets n=b^{d-1}+1, observes that in base b the expansion of n is (1,0,…,0,1)_b of length d, and then takes b_1=…=b_K=b to get a d-digit palindrome in each of the K bases.

attempts.solution:
Let the two positive integers K and d be given.  
(It is tacitly understood that every “base’’ that occurs is at least 2.)

We treat separately the cases d = 1 and d ≥ 2.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The one–digit case  d = 1
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Take  

  n = 1  and  b₁ = b₂ = ⋯ = b_K = 2.

Every base–2 expansion of a positive integer consists of the single
digit 1 only for the number 1 itself, so in each base b₁,…,b_K the
number n = 1 is a 1-digit palindrome.  
(The same statement would be true for any choice b_i ≥ 2; we fixed the
value 2 just for definiteness.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The case  d ≥ 2
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Choose the number  

  n = 2^{\,d-1}+1.                                               (1)

Because 2^{d-1} is the highest power of 2 not exceeding n, the binary
(expansion in base 2) of n is obtained from the
binary word for 2^{d-1} – namely a 1 followed by d−1 zeros – by adding
1.  Hence the base-2 representation of n is  

  1 0 0 … 0 1                                                     (2)

(the digit 1, then d−2 zeros, then another digit 1).  
This word has exactly d digits and reads the same from left to right and
from right to left; in other words, (2) is a d-digit palindrome in base 2.

Now set  

  b₁ = b₂ = ⋯ = b_K = 2.                                         (3)

By construction (2), the integer n given in (1) is a d-digit palindrome
in every one of the bases b₁,…,b_K. 

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For every choice of the positive integers K and d we have produced

 • a positive integer n (namely 1 if d=1 and 2^{d-1}+1 if d≥2), and   
 • a sequence of K positive integers b₁,…,b_K (all equal to 2),

such that n is a d-digit palindrome in each of the bases b₁,…,b_K.
This completes the proof. ∎

result.summary: The proof handles two cases: for d=1 it takes n=1 and all bases b_i=2, so n=1 is a one-digit palindrome in each base; for d≥2 it sets n=2^{d-1}+1 and again all b_i=2, then argues that the binary expansion of n is the d-digit palindrome “1 followed by d−2 zeros then 1,” proving n is a d-digit palindrome in each base.

issues.description: The proof claims the binary representation has exactly d digits but does not justify how the number of digits is determined (e.g. via floor of logarithm plus one).

attempts.solution:
To prove that for any given positive integers $ K $ and $ d $, there exists a positive integer $ n $ and a sequence of $ K $ positive integers $ b_1, b_2, \dots, b_K $ such that $ n $ is a $ d $-digit palindrome in all number bases $ b_1, b_2, \dots, b_K $, we proceed by considering the structure of palindromic numbers in positional number systems.

---

### **Understanding the Problem**

A $ d $-digit number $ n $ in base $ b $ is a palindrome if its digits in base $ b $ read the same forwards and backwards. That is, if:

$$
n = a_0 b^{d-1} + a_1 b^{d-2} + \cdots + a_1 b + a_0,
$$

where $ a_0, a_1, \dots, a_{\lfloor d/2 \rfloor} $ are digits in base $ b $, satisfying $ 0 \leq a_i < b $, and $ a_0 \neq 0 $ (to ensure it's a $ d $-digit number).

Our goal is to **construct** a number $ n $ and a sequence of $ K $ bases $ b_1, b_2, \dots, b_K $ such that $ n $ is a $ d $-digit palindrome in each of those bases.

---

### **Key Insight**

We are **not required** to use distinct bases. This is crucial. If we are allowed to use the **same base** for all $ K $ positions, the problem becomes significantly easier.

Let us fix a base $ b $, and construct a number $ n $ that is a $ d $-digit palindrome in base $ b $. Then, we can simply set all $ b_i = b $, and the number $ n $ will be a $ d $-digit palindrome in all $ K $ bases.

---

### **Constructing a Suitable $ n $**

We can construct a simple $ d $-digit palindrome in base $ b $ by choosing:

$$
n = b^{d-1} + 1.
$$

This number has the following representation in base $ b $:

- The most significant digit is 1 (from $ b^{d-1} $),
- The least significant digit is 1 (from the constant term),
- All other digits are 0.

This gives the digit sequence $ 100\ldots001 $, which is a palindrome of length $ d $.

We now verify that this $ n $ is indeed a $ d $-digit number in base $ b $:

- The smallest $ d $-digit number in base $ b $ is $ b^{d-1} $,
- The largest is $ b^d - 1 $,
- Since $ b^{d-1} \leq b^{d-1} + 1 < b^d $, the number $ n $ is a valid $ d $-digit number in base $ b $.

---

### **Final Construction**

Let $ b $ be any integer greater than or equal to 2 (since base 1 is not standard for positional numeral systems).

Define:

- $ n = b^{d-1} + 1 $,
- $ b_1 = b_2 = \cdots = b_K = b $.

Then $ n $ is a $ d $-digit palindrome in base $ b $, and since all $ b_i = b $, $ n $ is a $ d $-digit palindrome in all $ K $ bases.

This construction is valid for all positive integers $ K $ and $ d $, including the case $ d = 1 $, where any number less than the base is a 1-digit number (and thus a palindrome).

---

### **Conclusion**

We have shown that for any positive integers $ K $ and $ d $, we can construct a number $ n $ and a sequence of $ K $ bases (not necessarily distinct) such that $ n $ is a $ d $-digit palindrome in each of those bases. This construction is valid and satisfies all the conditions of the problem.

$$
\boxed{n}
$$

result.summary: The proof observes that the problem allows repeating bases, so one can pick any base \(b\ge2\), let \(n=b^{d-1}+1\) which in base \(b\) has the digit expansion \(100\ldots001\), a palindrome of length \(d\), and then set all \(b_i=b\) for \(i=1,\dots,K\). This immediately yields a \(d\)-digit palindrome in each of the \(K\) bases.

issues.text: “We are **not required** to use distinct bases. This is crucial. If we are allowed to use the same base for all $ K $ positions, the problem becomes significantly easier.”
issues.description: The proof trivializes the problem by assuming without justification that one may repeat the same base across all $K$ positions. While the statement does not explicitly forbid repeats, this assumption bypasses any nontrivial aspect of choosing $K$ different bases.

issues.text: “including the case $ d = 1 $, where any number less than the base is a 1-digit number (and thus a palindrome).”
issues.description: For $d=1$, the construction gives $n=b^{0}+1=2$, which in base $b=2$ is represented as “10” (a 2-digit string), not a 1-digit palindrome. The proof does not explain how to choose $b$ to handle the $d=1$ case correctly.

issues.text: “This gives the digit sequence $100\ldots001$, which is a palindrome of length $d$. ”
issues.description: The proof asserts the base-$b$ expansion of $b^{d-1}+1$ has zeros in all intermediate positions without showing why no carries occur or why exactly $d-2$ zeros appear. It skips this straightforward computation.
The proof concludes with an isolated “$\\boxed{n}$” rather than clearly restating the constructed integer $n$ and the sequence of bases $(b_1,\dots,b_K)$, leaving the conclusion incomplete.

attempts.solution:
Let \(d\) and \(K\) be given positive integers. We want to find a positive integer \(n\) and \(K\) distinct positive integers \(b_1, \ldots, b_K\) such that \(n\) is a \(d\)-digit palindrome in each base \(b_j\).

Case 1: \(d=1\).
A number \(n\) is a 1-digit palindrome in base \(b\) if its representation is \((a_0)_b\) with \(a_0 \ne 0\). The palindrome condition \(a_0 = a_{1-1-0}\) is trivially satisfied. We also need \(1 \le a_0 < b\).
Let \(n=K+1\). Choose \(b_j = K+1+j\) for \(j=1, \ldots, K\).
Then for each \(j\), \(b_j = K+1+j > K+1 = n\).
So \(n\) is a 1-digit number in base \(b_j\), represented as \((n)_{b_j}\).
The digit is \(a_0 = n = K+1\).
We have \(a_0 = K+1 \ne 0\).
We have \(1 \le a_0 < b_j\) because \(1 \le K+1 < K+1+j\) for \(j \ge 1\).
The bases \(b_j = K+1+j\) are distinct.
Thus, for \(d=1\), such \(n\) and \(b_1, \ldots, b_K\) exist. For example, we can take \(n=1\) and \(b_j = j+1\); then \(n=(1)_{j+1}\) for $j=1, \dots, K$. The bases must be $\ge 2$, so $b_j = \max(2, j+1)$. Or simply $b_j = j+C$ for a constant $C \ge 1$ such that $j+C \ge 2$. For $n=1$, choose $b_j = j+1$. Then $b_j \ge 2$. $n=(1)_{b_j}$. $a_0=1$. $1 \le 1 < j+1$ for $j \ge 1$.

Case 2: \(d \ge 2\).
Let's try to construct \(n\) such that its representation in base \(b_j\) is of the form \((x_j, 0, \ldots, 0, x_j)_{b_j}\).
This means that the $(d-1)$-th digit is $x_j$, the $0$-th digit is $x_j$, and all intermediate digits $a_{d-2,j}, \ldots, a_{1,j}$ are $0$.
The value of such a number \(n\) in base \(b_j\) is \(n = x_j b_j^{d-1} + x_j \cdot b_j^0 = x_j(b_j^{d-1}+1)\).
For this to be a valid representation of a \(d\)-digit palindrome, we need:
1.  \(x_j \ne 0\) (specifically, \(x_j \ge 1\) as it's a positive integer coefficient).
2.  All digits must be less than the base \(b_j\). So \(x_j < b_j\) and \(0 < b_j\) (which is true if $x_j < b_j$ and $x_j \ge 1$).
3.  The bases \(b_j\) must be integers \(\ge 2\).
4.  The bases \(b_j\) must be distinct.

Let \(x_j = j\) for \(j=1, \ldots, K\). So we require \(j < b_j\).
We need to find an integer \(n\) and distinct integer bases \(b_1, \ldots, b_K\) such that for each \(j \in \{1, \ldots, K\}\):
\(n = j(b_j^{d-1}+1)\) and \(b_j > j\), and \(b_j \ge 2\).

From \(n = j(b_j^{d-1}+1)\), we have \(b_j^{d-1}+1 = n/j\).
This implies that \(n\) must be divisible by \(j\) for all \(j=1, \ldots, K\).
Let \(L = \text{lcm}(1, 2, \ldots, K)\). Then \(n\) must be a multiple of \(L\).
Let \(n = M L\) for some positive integer \(M\).
Then \(b_j^{d-1}+1 = ML/j\).
So \(b_j^{d-1} = ML/j - 1\).
This implies \(b_j = (ML/j - 1)^{1/(d-1)}\).
For \(b_j\) to be an integer, \(ML/j - 1\) must be a perfect \((d-1)\)-th power of an integer.
Let \(P = d-1\). So \(P \ge 1\) as \(d \ge 2\).
We need \(ML/j - 1 = Z_j^P\) for some integer \(Z_j\). Then \(b_j=Z_j\).
The conditions become:
(a) \(Z_j\) must be an integer for each \(j\). So \(ML/j-1\) must be a \(P\)-th power.
(b) \(b_j > j\), which means \(Z_j > j\). This implies \(Z_j^P > j^P\), so \(ML/j - 1 > j^P\). This means \(ML/j > j^P+1\), or \(M > \frac{j(j^P+1)}{L}\).
(c) \(b_j \ge 2\), which means \(Z_j \ge 2\). This implies \(Z_j^P \ge 2^P\), so \(ML/j-1 \ge 2^P\). This means \(ML/j \ge 2^P+1\). This is usually stronger than (b) for \(j=1\); if \(j \ge 2\), then \(j^P \ge 2^P\). The condition $Z_j > j$ implies $Z_j \ge j+1$. If $j \ge 1$, then $j+1 \ge 2$, so $Z_j \ge 2$. Thus, $Z_j > j$ implies $Z_j \ge 2$.
(d) \(b_j\) must be distinct. Since \(b_j = Z_j\), \(Z_j\) must be distinct.

Let's choose the integers \(Z_j\) first, and then find \(M\).
Let \(Z_j = A \cdot (L/j)\) for some large integer \(A\).
Since \(L\) is a multiple of \(j\), \(L/j\) is an integer. So \(Z_j\) is an integer.
To make \(Z_j\) distinct for different \(j\), this choice is good: if \(A L/j_1 = A L/j_2\), then \(j_1=j_2\) (assuming $A \ne 0$).
The condition \(Z_j > j\) becomes \(A L/j > j\), or \(A > j^2/L\).
We can choose \(A\) large enough to satisfy this for all \(j=1, \ldots, K\). For example, choose \(A > \max_{j} \{j^2/L\}\), e.g., \(A = K^2+1\) (since \(L \ge 1\), \(j^2/L \le K^2\)).
So set \(b_j = A L/j\) for \(A = K^2+1\). These $b_j$ are distinct and $b_j > j$.
Now we need to define \(M\) such that \(ML/j - 1 = b_j^P = (A L/j)^P\).
So \(ML/j = (A L/j)^P + 1\).
This gives \(M = \frac{j}{L} \left( \left(\frac{AL}{j}\right)^P + 1 \right) = \frac{j}{L} \frac{(AL)^P}{j^P} + \frac{j}{L} = \frac{(AL)^P}{L j^{P-1}} + \frac{j}{L}\).
This value of \(M\) must be an integer, and it must be the same for all \(j=1, \ldots, K\).
If \(P=1\) (i.e., \(d=2\)):
\(M = \frac{AL}{L j^0} + \frac{j}{L} = A + \frac{j}{L}\).
For \(M\) to be an integer, \(L\) must divide \(j\). This is only true if \(L=1\), which means \(K=1\).
If \(K>1\), then \(L>1\). For \(j=1\), \(M=A+1/L\), which is not an integer.
So this choice of \(Z_j\) does not work generally.

Let's try a different approach for ensuring $ML/j-1 = Z_j^P$.
Let $Y$ be a sufficiently large integer.
Consider $j=1, \ldots, K$. We define $Z_j = Y + (K-j)$. These $Z_j$ are distinct integers.
Choose $Y$ large enough such that $Z_j > j$ for all $j$. For example, $Y=K+1$ makes $Z_j = K+1+K-j = 2K+1-j$. Then $Z_j > j$ means $2K+1-j > j \iff 2K+1 > 2j \iff K+1/2 > j$. This holds for all $j \le K$.
Also $Z_j \ge 2K+1-K = K+1 \ge 2$. So $b_j = Z_j \ge 2$.
The values $b_j = Z_j$ are then $Y, Y+1, \ldots, Y+K-1$ (if ordered by $K-j$ increasing). Or simply let $b_j = Y+j-1$. Choose $Y$ large enough such that $Y > K$. (e.g. $Y=K+1$). Then $b_j = K+j \ge K+1 > j$.
Let $b_j$ be these chosen integers.
We need $ML/j - 1 = b_j^P$.
So $ML/j = b_j^P+1$.
This means $M = \frac{j(b_j^P+1)}{L}$.
This \(M\) must be an integer and must be the same for all \(j\).
Let $N_0 = ML$. We need $N_0 = j(b_j^P+1)$ for all $j=1, \ldots, K$.
This means $N_0$ must be a multiple of $j$ and $b_j^P+1$.
The system of equations is $N_0 = j(b_j^P+1)$.
This implies $1 \cdot (b_1^P+1) = 2 \cdot (b_2^P+1) = \ldots = K \cdot (b_K^P+1) (= N_0)$.
Let $b_j$ be defined by these equations.
$b_j^P+1 = N_0/j$. So $b_j = (N_0/j - 1)^{1/P}$.
We need to find an integer $N_0$ such that:
1.  $N_0$ is a multiple of $L = \text{lcm}(1, \ldots, K)$.
2.  For each $j \in \{1, \ldots, K\}$, $N_0/j - 1$ is a perfect $P$-th power of an integer. Let $N_0/j - 1 = Z_j^P$.
3.  The integers $Z_j$ (which are our $b_j$) must satisfy $Z_j > j$.
4.  The integers $Z_j$ must be distinct. (If $Z_j=Z_k$, then $N_0/j-1 = N_0/k-1 \implies j=k$, so they are distinct).

Let $P=d-1$. We are looking for $N_0$ such that $N_0 \equiv 0 \pmod L$ and $N_0 \equiv j \pmod{j Z^P}$ for any $Z$. More accurately, $N_0/j - 1 = Z_j^P$. This is equivalent to $N_0 \equiv j \pmod{j \cdot Z_j^P}$ for some integers $Z_j$. Not quite.
This is $N_0 \equiv j \pmod{j \cdot (\text{anything if } P \text{ is odd, or specific conditions if } P \text{ is even}) }$.
This is a system of congruences: For each $j \in \{1, \ldots, K\}$, $N_0 \equiv j \pmod{j \cdot Y_j^P}$ for some $Y_j$. No.

Consider the system of congruences:
For $j=1, \ldots, K$:
$X \equiv 1 \pmod{j}$ (This means $X/j$ is integer. No, this means $X-1$ is a multiple of $j$. This isn't what $N_0/j-1$ means.)
We need $N_0/j - 1$ to be a $P$-th power. Let $k_j = N_0/j$. We need $k_j-1$ to be a $P$-th power.
This can be ensured by the Chinese Remainder Theorem (CRT).
Let $p_1, \ldots, p_K$ be $K$ distinct prime numbers, all greater than $K$. (Such primes exist by Euclid's theorem).
Let $Z_j = p_j$ for $j=1, \ldots, K$. Then $Z_j > K \ge j$. So $b_j=Z_j > j$ is satisfied.
We want $N_0/j - 1 = p_j^P$.
So $N_0 = j(p_j^P+1)$.
This implies $N_0$ must satisfy the system of equations:
$N_0 = 1(p_1^P+1)$
$N_0 = 2(p_2^P+1)$
...
$N_0 = K(p_K^P+1)$

Consider the system of congruences for $N_0$:
$N_0 \equiv 0 \pmod{j(p_j^P+1)}$ is not what we want.
We need to find $N_0$ such that $N_0 = j(p_j^P+1)$ holds for all $j$. This implies $j_1(p_{j_1}^P+1) = j_2(p_{j_2}^P+1)$. This is unlikely to hold for arbitrary distinct primes $p_j$.

Let's use a known result from number theory (related to Waring's problem or similar Diophantine systems). It is known that for any set of positive integers $c_1, \ldots, c_K$, and $P \ge 1$, the system of equations $X_j^P - c_j Y_j^P = 1$ has solutions. This is not general enough.

Let's use a different construction for the palindrome structure. Let $n$ be represented in base $b_j$ as $(1,0,\dots,0,1)_{b_j}$ if $d \ge 2$.
Then $n = b_j^{d-1}+1$. If $d-1 \ge 1$, then $x \mapsto x^{d-1}+1$ is strictly increasing for $x \ge 1$. So $b_j$ must all be equal, which is not allowed if $K>1$. This works for $K=1$.

What if $d=2$? We require $n = j(b_j+1)$. Let $L = \text{lcm}(1, \ldots, K)$.
Choose $M_0 = K(K+1)$. Let $n = M_0 L$.
Then $M_0 L = j(b_j+1)$, so $b_j+1 = M_0 L/j$. Since $j \le K$, $L/j$ is an integer.
So $b_j = M_0 L/j - 1$.
$b_j$ are integers. They are distinct: if $M_0L/j_1-1 = M_0L/j_2-1$, then $j_1=j_2$.
We need $b_j > j$.
$M_0 L/j - 1 > j \iff M_0 L/j > j+1 \iff M_0 > j(j+1)/L$.
Since $j \le K$, $j(j+1) \le K(K+1)$.
So $j(j+1)/L \le K(K+1)/L$.
Our choice $M_0 = K(K+1)$ ensures $M_0 \ge j(j+1)/L$ if $L \ge 1$. (If $L=1$, then $M_0 = K(K+1)$).
Thus $b_j > j$ is satisfied. For example, if $j=K$, we need $M_0 > K(K+1)/L$. $K(K+1) > K(K+1)/L$. This holds if $L>1$.

Proof.  Fix positive integers \(K\) and \(d\).  We will exhibit a positive integer \(n\) and \(K\) bases \(b_{1},\dots,b_{K}\) in which \(n\) has exactly \(d\) digits and is a palindrome.

1.  Choice of the bases.  
Let \(p_{1},p_{2},\dots,p_{K}\) be \(K\) distinct primes, each greater than \(1\).  For \(j=1,\dots,K\), set
\[
b_{j} \;:=\; p_{j}\,.
\]
Then the integers
\[
m_{j} \;:=\; b_{j}^{d}
\]
are pairwise coprime, since they are powers of distinct primes.

2.  A convenient \(d\)-digit palindrome in each base.  
Fix an index \(j\).  Consider the integer
\[
r_{j}
\;:=\;
1 + b_{j} + b_{j}^{2} + \cdots + b_{j}^{\,d-1}
\;=\;
\frac{b_{j}^{d}-1}{b_{j}-1}\,.
\]
Since \(0\le1<b_{j}\), the base-\(b_{j}\) expansion of \(r_{j}\) is
\[
r_{j}
\;=\;
\overbrace{11\cdots1}^{d\text{ digits in base }b_{j}}\,.
\]
In particular
\[
1\;\le\;r_{j}\;<\;b_{j}^{d},
\]
and the leading digit (the coefficient of \(b_{j}^{d-1}\)) is \(1\neq0\), so \(r_{j}\) really is a \(d\)-digit number in base \(b_{j}\).  Moreover, all its digits are equal to \(1\), hence it is a palindrome of length \(d\).

3.  Simultaneous congruences and the Chinese Remainder Theorem.  
We now impose the system of congruences
\[
\begin{cases}
n\;\equiv\;r_{1}\pmod{m_{1}},\\
n\;\equiv\;r_{2}\pmod{m_{2}},\\
\quad\vdots\\
n\;\equiv\;r_{K}\pmod{m_{K}}.
\end{cases}
\]
Since \(\gcd(m_{i},m_{j})=1\) for \(i\neq j\), by the Chinese Remainder Theorem there exists an integer \(n\) satisfying all \(K\) congruences simultaneously.  Moreover there are infinitely many such \(n\); in particular we may choose one positive.

4.  Verification that \(n\) is a \(d\)-digit palindrome in each base \(b_{j}\).  
Fix \(j\).  From
\[
n \;\equiv\; r_{j}
\pmod{\,b_{j}^{d}\,}
\]
we see that the least significant \(d\) base-\(b_{j}\) digits of \(n\) coincide with those of \(r_{j}\).  But \(r_{j}<b_{j}^{d}\), so in fact the full base-\(b_{j}\) expansion of \(n\) has exactly \(d\) digits, namely the same \(d\) digits as \(r_{j}\).  Since \(r_{j}\) is “111…1” in base \(b_{j}\), it follows that
\[
n
=
\overbrace{11\cdots1}^{d\text{ digits}}
\quad\text{in base }b_{j},
\]
which is manifestly a palindrome of length \(d\).

Conclusion.  Defining \(b_{1},\dots,b_{K}\) and \(n\) as above, we have constructed a single positive integer \(n\) whose base-\(b_{j}\) expansion is a \(d\)-digit palindrome for every \(j=1,\dots,K\).  This completes the proof.  ∎

result.summary: The proof picks K distinct primes p_j and sets b_j=p_j.  It defines r_j=1+b_j+⋯+b_j^{d-1}, whose base-b_j expansion is d copies of the digit 1, hence a d-digit palindrome.  Then, letting m_j=b_j^d, the Chinese Remainder Theorem produces an integer n with n≡r_j (mod m_j) for each j.  Finally, it asserts that in base b_j the number n has the same d least‐significant digits as r_j and so is the palindrome “111…1” of length d in each base.

issues.location: Step 4, concluding that n has exactly d digits in base b_j
issues.text: “But r_j<b_j^d, so in fact the full base-\(b_j\) expansion of n has exactly d digits, namely the same d digits as r_j.”
issues.description: The proof assumes without justification that the CRT solution n satisfies n<b_j^d.  In reality CRT only guarantees n≡r_j mod b_j^d, so n may exceed b_j^d and have more than d digits in base b_j.
